Award.AwardTitle: SNM GOALI: Carbon Nanotube Superfiber to Revolutionize Engineering Designs

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Scalable Nanomanufacturing (SBM) project aims to fundamentally modify nanotube synthesis and processing steps enabling the properties of nanotube superfiber to exceed those of existing fibers. Different forms of superfiber including yarn, braid, sheet, and fabric materials will be prepared. The approach to form superfiber is by synthesizing carbon nanotube arrays or forests of nanotubes, post-treating the arrays, and spinning the arrays into fibers. Technical advancements will be achieved in this project based on experimental, analytical and computational approaches that enable scale-up of the extraordinary properties of short nanotubes to bulk fibrous materials. The major technical roadblock to scale-up is that defects occur during manufacturing of long nanotube arrays. To remove this barrier, new methods and approaches of substrate engineering, base flow synthesis, thermal healing of defects, micro-spinning, and coating will be combined to improve the quality of nanotubes. The expected outcome is to design carbon nanotube superfiber materials with breakthrough properties, and to scale up superfiber manufacturing for commercialization.

The broader impact of this project will be to allow industries to replace their incumbent materials with superfiber materials that are lighter, tougher, stronger, and carry more electrical current. This project will provide the technical horsepower needed to close the gap between the properties of short research-grade nanotubes and commercial nanotube bulk materials, thus enabling American industry to manufacture a new fiber material which will revolutionize the engineering designs of dozens of products. The research will provide a better understanding why nanotubes have defects, why nanotubes stop growing, why fiber does not achieve the strength of nanotubes, and how to overcome these barriers. This project will also design new spinning and post processing approaches for long nanotubes that allow manufacturing scale-up and commercialization. An academic-corporate collaboration will help to transition the new technology into applications. Education and outreach activity in the project will focus on teaching students including underrepresented and high school students about nanotechnology and product innovation. An international Nanotechnology Materials Workshop will be held each year and include student presenters. Research results will be disseminated through editing a book on nanotube superfiber, journal and conference publications, and a web site. Results from the project will be integrated into classroom teaching.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon Nanotube Superfiber to Revolutionize Engineering Designs

The SNM GOALI project investigated the synthesis and post-processing of carbon nanotube (CNT) yarn to improve its properties (strength and conductivity). Various new applications for the yarn were also proposed. Nanotube yarn was produced in two ways: by drawing nanotube forests from a substrate and twisting (like spinning cotton), or by drawing a nanotube sock from the gas phase method and densifying and twisting. Drawing yarn from a forest of nanotubes was investigated and the limitation is that only short nanotubes (0.5 mm tall) are spinable into yarn. Long nanotubes (1 cm) in a forest were grown but they have defects and cannot be spun practically into yarn. It was possible to partially heal the defects in the long nanotubes through thermal annealing which produced high purity nanotubes. Forming nanotube yarn from a sock by densifying and twisting has the limitation the nanotubes are short (1 mm) which limits the properties of yarn. Also, about 20% iron catalyst left in and on the nanotubes. The investigations in the project also led to the conclusion that a modified method is needed for growing carbon nanotubes. Multi-physics and multi-chemistry methods were then proposed and initially investigated but mainly will be investigated in future projects. Multi-physics provides additional fields (beyond just the thermal heating field) to better control the synthesis process. Multi-chemistry has to do with new fuel compositions and additives that can affect nanotube nucleation, yield, and nanotube properties. These methods have not been investigated before. New applications of nanotube yarn and sheet were invented in the project and are in the areas of multifunctional composite materials (see figure), structural health monitoring, structural energy generation and storage, water filtration, firefighter protective garments, carbon electric motors (see figure), micro-robots for medicine (see figure), and other applications. The project trained undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctors, published a wide range of papers, edited a top selling book (a second edition is planned), and produced many invention disclosures. New multi-physics and multi-chemistry reactor technology and various application ideas are planned to be transitioned to industry for commercialization. Carbon Nanotube Superfiber is still in its early development stage, and the material properties will be continuously improved, and it is going to revolutionize engineering designs. The benefit to society is that carbon nanotube materials will replace metals (aluminum and copper) in weight critical applications which will increase the performance, efficiency, and safety of dynamic systems such as aircraft, space craft, transportation systems, your future automobile, wind energy generators, sporting equipment, electrical systems, biomedical micro-devices, and almost any system where dynamic performance and multifunctionality are important.


Last Modified: 03/16/2016
Modified by: Mark J Schulz
